headline: Police Complaint Data Shows A Broken Accountability Process

altHeadlines.value: The fundamental truths behind how complaints are processed by police departments
How race plays a role in police complaints.
How officer complaints are investigated: a case study for Philadelphia police

intro.value: In the current wake of police violence, protestors are demanding a stronger accountability for officer conduct and misuse of force. In many cities, that accountability is partly served by the civilian complaint process, or how citizens can individually report on police behavior.

Police complaints by citizens, ranging from physical abuse to unprofessional conduct, rarely result in consequences for officers. Concrete data is rare among departments, but in 2017, the Philadelphia Police Department became one of the few to report on every officer complaint it received. The patterns found in Philadelphia clarify many of the anecdotal observations across departments throughout the country, especially when it comes to racial disparities (e.g., complaints of White officers by Black civilians).
This is a real complaint about verbal abuse, one among 10,000+ complaints dating back to 2013.

sampleComplaint1: While Philadelphia’s public complaint data hides the identities of those involved, the records include the race and gender of the officer and person filing the complaint.

sampleComplaint2.value: While complaint investigations in some cities are conducted by civilian oversight boards, in Philadelphia, investigations are conducted by the police department’s own Internal Affairs division.
In the case of this complaint, the investigation, like all complaints in Philadelphia, is conducted behind closed doors and much of the decision-making process is hidden from public view.

For this complaint, the police’s investigation of the officer’s alleged verbal abuse is classified as no sustained findings. This is legalese for the police department finding there was not sufficient evidence to back up the citizen’s complaint.

sunburst1.value: In Philadelphia, the police department drops an overwhelming majority of cases: in the seven years of available data, just 16% of complaints have a sustained finding—meaning they believed there was enough evidence to support the complaint.

This aligns with studies from other city police departments, where the rate can range from 6% to 20%. While officer complaints in Philadelphia are investigated by police, some evidence exists that investigations involving a civilian oversight board are more likely to result in sustained findings.

sunburst2.value: Sustained complaints do not immediately result in punishment for officers—cases are first passed to an officer’s commander.

The officer’s commander can make a disciplinary decision on their own or may pass the complaint to the Police Board of Inquiry for a disciplinary hearing, conducted by three members of the police department who make a disciplinary recommendation. Their report is then sent to the Police Commissioner for a final decision on disciplinary action.

Only 2%, or 218 of the 11,107 complaints since 2013, result in a guilty finding and consequently the officer is reprimanded, terminationed, suspended, or criminal charged (the data doesn’t make any distinctions among these outcomes).

sunburst3.value: In line with decades of prior research, race correlates strongly with guilty outcomes.
For example, when a complaint is made by a white civilian, guilty findings increase from 2% to 3%.

sunburst4.value: While complaints by Black civilians are far more common in Philadelphia, guilty rates more than halve to 1.3% (compared to 3% for white civilians), underscoring the disparities in which Black communities are policed and a particular lack of accountability for officer actions.

sunburst5.value: This guilty finding rate shrinks even further for complaints filed against white officers. Just 22 of the 3,698, or 0.6%, of complaints against white officers filed by Black complainants result in a guilty finding. White officers are consistently less likely to face disciplinary action than their peers.

sunburst6.value: Conversely, complaints by white civilians against Black officers have one of the highest rate of guilty findings of 3.8%, underscoring that the complaint process is not only more dismissive towards Black complainants, but more punitive towards Black officers.

tilechart1.value: This visual represents each disciplinary investigation as a single square.

tilechart2.value: As of 2019, Philadelphia began redacting full details of complaints and replacing them with boilerplate 1-2 sentence summaries. Full summaries for complaints before July 2018 are provided, courtesy of Philly Declaration's Police Accountability Project, which published datasets before the city began redacting summaries.

tilechart3.value: Here, the complaints have been color-coded based on the number of known prior complaints for the involved officer at the time of a complaint. Note that this tabulation is based only on the complaints dating back to 2013 that have been provided to the public, so these officers could have any number of additional complaints from 2012 or earlier. Like many other cities, a small group of officers in Philadelphia account for a disproportionate number of complaints. Over a dozen officers, recently identified, have been involved in ten or more publicly-disclosed complaints.

tilechart4.value: The investigations have been filtered to include only "Physical Abuse" investigations, often filed in response to police use of force. As rare as guilty findings are in general, they’re even more rare in these investigations. Just 5 of 1493, or 0.3%, physical abuse investigations resulted in guilty findings while just 23, or 1.5%, have resulted in any kind of sustained finding Prior research involving other departments has found similar patterns.

conclusion.value: Philadelphia provides more publicly accessible data on police complaints and officer-involved shootings than almost any other major U.S. city. It is an important first step in holding police departments accountable, yet complaint summaries are redacted, disciplinary decision processes remain vague, and anonymized IDs replace the names of officers with more than a dozen recorded complaints. The lack of meaningful civilian review makes the investigative and disciplinary processes even more opaque. In order to hold institutions accountable, data and processes must not only be public, but also transparent.
